pageProps.contentHtml:
harmonic functions, Harnack's inequality

Let {un(z)}n\set{u_n\p{z}}_n{un​(z)}n​ be a sequence of real-valued harmonic functions on D≔{z∈C∣∣z∣<1}\D \coloneqq \set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} < 1}D:={z∈C∣∣z∣<1} that obey

u1(z)≥u2(z)≥u3(z)≥⋯≥0for all z∈D.u_1\p{z} \geq u_2\p{z} \geq u_3\p{z} \geq \cdots \geq 0 \quad\text{for all } z \in \D.u1​(z)≥u2​(z)≥u3​(z)≥⋯≥0for all z∈D.

Prove that z↦inf⁡nun(z)z \mapsto \inf_n u_n\p{z}z↦infn​un​(z) is a harmonic function on D\DD.
Solution.

Let 0<r<R<10 < r < R < 10<r<R<1 so that B(0,r)‾⊆B(0,R)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{0, r}} \subseteq \cl{B\p{0, R}} \subseteq \DB(0,r)​⊆B(0,R)​⊆D. Since {un}n\set{u_n}_n{un​}n​ is a decreasing sequence, we un−umu_n - u_mun​−um​ is a non-negative harmonic function for n≤mn \leq mn≤m. Thus, by Harnack's inequality, we have for any z∈B(0,r)‾z \in \cl{B\p{0, r}}z∈B(0,r)​ that

∣un(z)−um(z)∣=un(z)−um(z)≤R+rR−r(un(0)−um(0))=R+rR−r∣un(0)−um(0)∣.\abs{u_n\p{z} - u_m\p{z}} = u_n\p{z} - u_m\p{z} \leq \frac{R + r}{R - r}\p{u_n\p{0} - u_m\p{0}} = \frac{R + r}{R - r}\abs{u_n\p{0} - u_m\p{0}}.∣un​(z)−um​(z)∣=un​(z)−um​(z)≤R−rR+r​(un​(0)−um​(0))=R−rR+r​∣un​(0)−um​(0)∣.

Since {un(0)}n\set{u_n\p{0}}_n{un​(0)}n​ is a decreasing sequence bounded below (by 000), it is convergent, hence Cauchy. Thus, because r,Rr, Rr,R are independent of n,mn, mn,m, it follows that {un}n\set{u_n}_n{un​}n​ is uniformly Cauchy on compact sets, so it converges locally uniformly to u=inf⁡nunu = \inf_n u_nu=infn​un​. Since each unu_nun​ was continuous, locally uniform convergence implies that uuu is also continuous, so we may integrate.

Let B(z,R)B\p{z, R}B(z,R) be such that B(z,R)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{z, R}} \subseteq \DB(z,R)​⊆D. Then because unu_nun​ is harmonic,

un(z)=12π∫02πun(z+Reiθ) dθ.u_n\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} u_n\p{z + Re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta.un​(z)=2π1​∫02π​un​(z+Reiθ)dθ.

By uniform convergence, we may take n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞ and interchange the limit and integral to get

u(z)=12π∫02πu(z+Reiθ) dθ,u\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} u\p{z + Re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta,u(z)=2π1​∫02π​u(z+Reiθ)dθ,

so uuu satisfies the mean value property, hence harmonic. We reproduce the proof of this fact below:

Let

ρ(z)=Cexp⁡(−11−∣z∣2)χD(z)\rho\p{z} = C\exp\p{-\frac{1}{1 - \abs{z}^2}} \chi_{\D\p{z}}ρ(z)=Cexp(−1−∣z∣21​)χD(z)​

with CCC such that ∥ρ∥L1=1\norm{\rho}_{L^1} = 1∥ρ∥L1​=1. Then ρ\rhoρ is a smooth function supported in D\DD. For ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, set ρε(z)=1ερ(zε)\rho_\epsilon\p{z} = \frac{1}{\epsilon}\rho\p{\frac{z}{\epsilon}}ρε​(z)=ε1​ρ(εz​) so that ρε\rho_\epsilonρε​ is supported on B(0,ε)B\p{0, \epsilon}B(0,ε) and set uε=ρε∗uu_\epsilon = \rho_\epsilon * uuε​=ρε​∗u.

Let z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D and ε\epsilonε small enough so that B(z,ε)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{z, \epsilon}} \subseteq \DB(z,ε)​⊆D. Then

uε(z)=∫B(0,ε)ρε(w)u(z−w) dw=∫0ε∫02πrρε(reiθ)u(z−reiθ) dθ dr=∫0εrρε(r)∫02πu(z−reiθ) dθ dr=∫0ε2πrρε(r)u(z) dr=u(z)∫0ε∫02πrρε(reiθ) dθ dr=u(z)∥ρε∥L1=u(z).\begin{aligned} u_\epsilon\p{z} &= \int_{B\p{0,\epsilon}} \rho_\epsilon\p{w} u\p{z - w} \,\diff{w} \\ &= \int_0^\epsilon \int_0^{2\pi} r\rho_\epsilon\p{re^{i\theta}} u\p{z - re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \,\diff{r} \\ &= \int_0^\epsilon r\rho_\epsilon\p{r} \int_0^{2\pi} u\p{z - re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \,\diff{r} \\ &= \int_0^\epsilon 2\pi r\rho_\epsilon\p{r} u\p{z} \,\diff{r} \\ &= u\p{z} \int_0^\epsilon \int_0^{2\pi} r\rho_\epsilon\p{re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \,\diff{r} \\ &= u\p{z} \norm{\rho_\epsilon}_{L^1} \\ &= u\p{z}. \end{aligned}uε​(z)​=∫B(0,ε)​ρε​(w)u(z−w)dw=∫0ε​∫02π​rρε​(reiθ)u(z−reiθ)dθdr=∫0ε​rρε​(r)∫02π​u(z−reiθ)dθdr=∫0ε​2πrρε​(r)u(z)dr=u(z)∫0ε​∫02π​rρε​(reiθ)dθdr=u(z)∥ρε​∥L1​=u(z).​

Thus, uε=uu_\epsilon = uuε​=u whenever ε\epsilonε is small enough, and because uεu_\epsilonuε​ is a convolution with a smooth function against a continuous function, it follows that uuu is also smooth. To show that uuu is harmonic, we have by the divergence theorem

∫B(z,R)Δu(w) dm=∫∂B(z,R)∇u(z+Reiθ)⋅(cos⁡θ,sin⁡θ) dθ=∫∂B(z,R)∂u∂x(z+Reiθ)cos⁡θ+∂u∂x(z+Reiθ)sin⁡θ dθ=∫∂B(z,R)∂u∂r(z+Reiθ) dθ=∂∂r∫∂B(z,R)u(z+Reiθ) dθ=0,\begin{aligned} \int_{B\p{z,R}} \Delta u\p{w} \,\diff{m} &= \int_{\partial B\p{z,R}} \nabla u\p{z + Re^{i\theta}} \cdot \p{\cos\theta, \sin\theta} \,\diff\theta \\ &= \int_{\partial B\p{z,R}} \pder{u}{x}\p{z + Re^{i\theta}} \cos\theta + \pder{u}{x}\p{z + Re^{i\theta}}\sin\theta \,\diff\theta \\ &= \int_{\partial B\p{z,R}} \pder{u}{r}\p{z + Re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \\ &= \pder{}{r} \int_{\partial B\p{z,R}} u\p{z + Re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \\ &= 0, \end{aligned}∫B(z,R)​Δu(w)dm​=∫∂B(z,R)​∇u(z+Reiθ)⋅(cosθ,sinθ)dθ=∫∂B(z,R)​∂x∂u​(z+Reiθ)cosθ+∂x∂u​(z+Reiθ)sinθdθ=∫∂B(z,R)​∂r∂u​(z+Reiθ)dθ=∂r∂​∫∂B(z,R)​u(z+Reiθ)dθ=0,​

since uuu satisfies the mean value property. Thus, because uuu is smooth, Δu\Delta uΔu is continuous, and so

Δu(z)=lim⁡R→01m(B(z,R))∫B(z,R)Δu(w) dw=0,\Delta u\p{z} = \lim_{R\to0} \frac{1}{m\p{B\p{z,R}}} \int_{B\p{z,R}} \Delta u\p{w} \,\diff{w} = 0,Δu(z)=R→0lim​m(B(z,R))1​∫B(z,R)​Δu(w)dw=0,

so uuu is harmonic.
